questions.text: A patient presents with a 1-year history of painful nodulocystic acne (as shown in the image). What is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral isotretinoin DOC for severe/grade 4 nodulocystic acne = Oral isotretinoin MOA: Reducing/inhibiting sebum secretion, also reducing inflammation. Indications: Severe acne/nodulocystic acne/acne conglobata/acne not responding to conventional therapy/acne which repeatedly relapses after conventional therapy (recalcitrant pustular acne). Dose: 0.5–1 mg/kg body weight daily.

Highyeild:

Acne It is a chronic disorder affecting the hair follicle and sebaceous Pathogenesis: Hypercornification of hair follicle opening The proliferation of P. acnes Excess sebum production Increase androgen secretion & IGF-1 Features: Open and closed non-inflamed comedones Inflamed papules and pustules Severe acne: Nodules and pseudocysts Post-inflammatory erythematous or pigmented macules and scars Severity: Mild acne : total lesion count <30 Moderate acne : total lesion count 30–125 Severe acne : total lesion count >125 Treatment: Mild acne: Topical anti-acne agents: benzoyl peroxide, azelaic acid, Antiseptics: Salicylic acid, Light/laser therapy Moderate acne: Tetracycline, Isotretinoin Severe acne: Oral antibiotics, oral isotretinoin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. and C: Topical clindamycin and topical adapalene can be used for mild to moderate acne, but are not effective for nodulocystic acne. Option D. Oral doxycycline: It can be used for moderate to severe acne, but oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne.

questions.text: Meissner’s corpuscles are present in which layer of skin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Papillary dermis Meissner’s corpuscles (Tactile corpuscles) are a type of mechanoreceptor located in the papillary dermis. Because of their superficial location in the dermis, these corpuscles are particularly sensitive to touch and vibrations.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of bullae involving >30% BSA along with rashes all over the body with erosions of the lips and another mucosa for a few days. What can be the triggering factor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drug-induced The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) as more than 30% BSA is involved. TEN is most commonly drug-induced.

Highyeild:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis It is a severe mucocutaneous reaction that is characterized by necrosis and detachment of the epidermis. Cause: Drugs Antiepileptics: Lamotrigine, phenytoin, phenobarbital and carbamazepine Anti-inflammatory: Piroxicam Anti-retroviral: Nevirapine, abacavir Sulfa antibiotics Infections and systemic illness Genetic predisposition Idiopathic Pathogenesis: CD8 and NK cell-mediated keratinocyte death Features: Atypical target lesions (2 zones only) Can also present as multiple bullous lesions or diffuse erythema Fever, arthralgia, myalgia may be present Based on maximal epidermal detachment, it is classified as Disease Epidermal detachment SJS <10% SJS-TEN overlap 10 to 30% TEN >30%

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C, D: Viral infection, bacterial infection, and idiopathic can also cause SJS/TEN but most commonly due to drugs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female has had asymptomatic dome-shaped small lesions on her face for the past 2 months. She lives with her 2-year-old daughter, also having similar lesions. What is the causative agent of the lesions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pox virus The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Molluscum contagiosum.

Highyeild:

Molluscum contagiosum Cause: Pox virus- Molluscum contagiosum virus Incubation period: 2 weeks Mode of spread: Direct skin-to-skin contact Indirect contact via shared towels or other items Auto-inoculation into another site by scratching or shaving: pseudo koebner's phenomenon Sexual transmission in adults Characteristics: Multiple, pearly white, dome-shaped papules which are umbilicated Under a hand lens, may have a mosaic appearance On piercing the umbilicated center, white cheesy material can be extruded Diagnosis : By dermatoscopy and skin biopsy: shows characteristics intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. Henderson Peterson bodies Treatment: Hydrogen peroxide cream/povidone-iodine Cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, and diluted liquefied phenol are strong irritants which can both cause pain, blistering, and scarring but with careful application and appropriate dilution can increase lesion clearance. Topical salicylic acid preparations, tretinoin, adapalene, nitric oxide cream and 5–10% potassium hydroxide solution, and benzoyl peroxide cream. Strains of Molluscum contagiosum virus: Virus Age Site MCV-1 Children Face MCV-2 Adults Genitals

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. HSV: It can cause cold sores or genital herpes, but the lesions are usually painful and/or itchy and may be accompanied by other symptoms, such as fever or swollen glands. Option C. HPV: It can cause warts on various parts of the body, including the face, and the lesions may have a similar appearance to molluscum contagiosum. However, HPV lesions do not typically have the characteristic central dimple or pit seen in molluscum contagiosum. Option D. VZV: It causes chickenpox and shingles, which present as blister-like lesions. The lesions of molluscum contagiosum are not blister-like and do not typically rupture or crust over like the lesions of VZV.

Table:

#MANTRA Inclusion bodies Intracytoplasmic Henderson Peterson Molluscum (Pox virus) Negri bodies Rabies Guarneri bodies Vaccinia Paschen bodies Varicella Bollinger bodies Fowl pox Borrel bodies Fowl pox Intranuclear Cowdry A Herpes, yellow fever Cowdry B Adenovirus, poliovirus

Candida: Yeast-like fungi which forms Pseudohyphae and budding at 20°C Germ tube at 37°C aka Reynolds Braude Phenomenon Can produce both Systemic and Superficial fungal infection: Oral Candidiasis Esophageal candidiasis: AIDS-defining illness, shaggy esophagus Candida onychomycosis Vulvovaginitis: Associated with antibiotic use and diabetes Candidiasis balanoposthitis: Swelling of the prepuce, radial fissuring Diaper rash Infective endocarditis: People who inject drugs Candidal intertrigo: skin folds Disseminated candidiasis: In neutropenia patients Treatment: Oral or topical azoles Nystatin Echinocandins and Amphotericin B for systemic diseases

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Vitamin supplements: Given if Vitamin B12 or iron deficiency is suspected if pale mucosa is present. Option C . Stop smoking and screen for carcinoma: Smoking can lead to leukoplakia which also presents as white patches on the tongue which are usually thick, raised, and have a rough texture, which may cause discomfort or pain, especially when eating or speaking. questions.text: A child patient comes to OPD with a history of black central arch rashes on his body. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meningococcemia The given clinical scenario with history of black central arch rashes on the body of a child patient is a characteristic finding of Meningococcemia.

Highyeild:

Acute meningococcemia Cause: Neisseria meningitidis. Features : In the primary stage , it may mimic a viral disease (nonspecific). It can present with a sudden onset of high fever, headache, and body aches. Any organ of the body can be affected by vasculitis and thromboembolic disease. Black central arch and surrounding ring or erythema is the characteristic meningococcal rash and it is often seen before more serious signs develop. Rapid progression is seen in a fulminant case with disseminated intravascular coagulation , septic shock, adrenal hemorrhage, acidosis, and renal and heart failure. Petechiae and purpura ± meningitis = purpura fulminans (DIC)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: It fever is a viral infection. While it can cause a rash, it typically presents as a maculopapular rash rather than a petechial rash. Option: C. Leptospirosis: It is a bacterial infection that is usually acquired through contact with contaminated water or soil. While it can cause a petechial rash, it is typically associated with symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle aches, and sometimes jaundice. Option: D. Scrub typhus: Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection that is transmitted by the bite of infected chiggers. It can cause a petechial rash, but it is typically associated with symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle aches, and sometimes lymphadenopathy.
